title: FreesearchR knowledge base
text:
Preface
This book will form the knowledge data base that goes with the FreesearchR project. This will contain a basic introduction to data science and data analysis as a foundation for starting to use the FreesearchR app.
Key motivations for this project are to

lower the barrier to do data analysis
empower clinicians to perform data analysis on own data locally
provide learners with basic knowledge to make informed decisions

The main audience for this project is clinicians, researchers and students with a need for basic analytical tools and knowledge to start interpreting clinical data. The methods used are general and can be used beyond this main audience.
This knowledge database will mainly consist of instructions and descriptions for the FreesearchR app as well as a collection of links and references for recommended further reading and learning.

title: 1  FreesearchR app intro
text:
1.1 The FreesearchR app
The FreesearchR app is published as an R-package for easy installation in a local R-environment and is also accessible directly online in your web browser.
Currently, the app introduction lives in the package documentation and is accessible here.

title: 2  Randomised clinical trial in stroke
text:
2.1 A clinical trial on neuroprotection in stroke
This case study will be based on the study “Neuroregeneration and Vascular Protection by Citalopram in Acute Ischemic Stroke (TALOS)”.(K. L. Kraglund et al. 2018)
We will not be able to include all data from this trial, but key tables and figures based on annonymised data from the trial included in the FreesearchR app will be used. These data are published for educational purposes in the “stRoke” package, which also includes a few tools for clinical stroke trials.(Damsbo 2023)
The TALOS trial was a randomised trial, with a predefined analysis plan and a published protocol.(K. Kraglund et al. 2015) As the trial was randomised, the main analyses where
crumbs: 2  Randomised clinical trial in stroke

title: 2  Randomised clinical trial in stroke
text:
2.1.1 Load the data
Start of by launching the FreesearchR app (click this link).

Go to the “Get started” tab,
under “Choose your data source”, select “Local or sample data”,
then under “Select data source”, select “stRoke”, and
then under “Select a dataset”, select “trial”.

This should load the data, and you can press the “Quick overview” to preview the data classes and missing values.
In the section “Select variables for final import”, you can decide to set a missingness threshold and specify variables to initially include. Leaves these options at the default for now. For this exercise, just include all variables.


2.1.2 Baseline characteristics
Having loaded the relevant dataset, we will go straight to generating a classic table for overview of the variables, typically what is included in papers as a Table 1.

Click the “Evaluate” panel and
select the “Characteristics” sub-panel in the dropdown.

This is the section, where the characteristics panel is generated.
In the sidebar

Under “Select variable to stratify baseline”, select “active” to stratify by active trial treatment, and
then click “Evaluate”, wait a second and have a look at the table generated.

The table can be exported in a document format.

Go to the “Download” panel at the top,
under “Report”, choose the desired document format (MS Word or LibreOffice), and
click “Download report”.

This will generate the report and it will get downloaded to your device. Find it in your downloads folder.


2.1.3 Visualise the classic outcome
The modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score has been used as the main outcome for a large number stroke trials.(“Tissue Plasminogen Activator for Acute Ischemic Stroke” 1995; Berkhemer et al. 2015; Blauenfeldt et al. 2023) The TALOS trial also used the mRS, but did not include a graph to show the distribution. Let’s create that graph now then:

Go to “Visuals”, and
select “mrs_6” as the “Response variable” to see plotting options, and
select “Stacked horizontal bars” and
select “active” as the secondary variable to stratify by trial treatment, then
click “Plot” to view the results.

To export the plot

Click the “Download” sidebar section to unfold the download options,
specify the details and select file format, and
click “Download”.

Open the plot locally to verify the results.


2.1.4 Now its time for experimentation
The above instructions are intended to introduce some of the functionality of the FreesearchR app. Please review the sections to experiment to explore the functions, but also to explore the data you are using. Here are some questions to think about:

What is the median age for men? And for women?
How is the distribution of of mRS score at 1 month?
How is the distribution of mRS score at 6 months grouped by sex?
In the trial introducing IVT treatment(“Tissue Plasminogen Activator for Acute Ischemic Stroke” 1995), several outcome scales were used and binned. How would this be done with the FreesearchR app?
…





Berkhemer, Olvert A., Puck S. S. Fransen, Debbie Beumer, Lucie A. van den Berg, Hester F. Lingsma, Albert J. Yoo, Wouter J. Schonewille, et al. 2015. “A Randomized Trial of Intraarterial Treatment for Acute Ischemic Stroke.” New England Journal of Medicine 372 (1): 11–20. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa1411587.


Blauenfeldt, Rolf Ankerlund, Niels Hjort, Jan Brink Valentin, Anne-Mette Homburg, Boris Modrau, Birgitte Forsom Sandal, Martin Faurholdt Gude, et al. 2023. “Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Acute Stroke.” JAMA 330 (13): 1236. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.2023.16893.


Damsbo, Andreas Gammelgaard. 2023. Agdamsbo/stRoke: stRoke 23.6.3. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/ZENODO.8013980.


Kraglund, Kristian Lundsgaard, Janne Kaergaard Mortensen, Andreas Gammelgaard Damsbo, Boris Modrau, Sofie Amalie Simonsen, Helle Klingenberg Iversen, Morten Madsen, Erik Lerkevang Grove, Søren Paaske Johnsen, and Grethe Andersen. 2018. “Neuroregeneration and Vascular Protection by Citalopram in Acute Ischemic Stroke (TALOS).” Stroke 49 (11): 2568–76. https://doi.org/10.1161/strokeaha.117.020067.


Kraglund, Kristian, Janne Mortensen, Erik Grove, Sren Paaske Johnsen, and Grethe Andersen. 2015. “TALOS: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial to Test the Effects of Citalopram in Patients with Acute Stroke.” International Journal of Stroke 10 (6): 985–87. https://doi.org/10.1111/ijs.12485.


“Tissue Plasminogen Activator for Acute Ischemic Stroke.” 1995. New England Journal of Medicine 333 (24): 1581–88. https://doi.org/10.1056/nejm199512143332401.
crumbs: 2  Randomised clinical trial in stroke

title: 3  Overlapping measures
text:
3.1 Overlapping measures
For the following case study on using the FreesearchR tool, the following article will be used as an example: Damsbo et al. (2020).
This article includes a table of baseline characteristics, a regression table and an Euler plot of overlapping markers of poor mental health after stroke. Based on an anonymised dataset, the basics of each of these elements will be recreated in the following.

title: 3  Overlapping measures
text:
3.1.1 The Euler plot
The Euler plot is an area-accurate plot of overlapping features. This can be used to visualise how patients suffer from several diseases or how symptoms of mental health are overlapping.
Plotting the Euler plot is based on dichotomised categorical variables (2 levels). In the FreesearchR app, categorical variables can be created from continuous data.


3.1.2 Load the data
Start of by launching the FreesearchR app (click this link).

Go to the “Get started” tab,
under “Choose your data source”, select “Local or sample data”,
then under “Select data source”, select “stRoke”, and
then under “Select a dataset”, select “trial”.

This should load the data, and you can press the “Quick overview” to preview the data classes and missing values.
In the section “Select variables for final import”, you can decide to set a missingness threshold and specify variables to initially include. Leaves these options at the default for now. For this exercise, just include all variables.


3.1.3 Baseline characteristics
See ?sec-trial_baseline on how to create a baseline characteristics table.


3.1.4 Plotting
Now on to the plotting. I will start by showing how to visualise the overlapping features of hypertension, diabetes and living alone:

Open the “Visuals” panel,
select “hypertension” as the “Response variable” to see plotting options, and
select “Euler diagram” and
select “diabetes” and “cohabitation” as “Additional variables”,
click “Plot”.


3.1.4.1 Creating categorical variables
If you want to create new dichotomous (2-level categorical) variables from continuous data, then follow the below steps (as an exaple the “mfi_6” variable will be used):

Go to “Prepare” -> “Edit and create data”, the
select “New factor” (factor is the technical term for a categorical variable), and then
in the pop-up window, under “Variable to cut”, select “mfi_6”,
keep the “Method” “fixed”, and choose “2” under “Number of breaks” to create a categorical variable with 2 levels.
Select the cut-off between the two levels to 12 for the “mfi_6” variable, and then
click “Create factor variable”.

A new variable called “mfi_6_cut” is now created. Repeat the above steps for other variables you want to cut.


3.1.4.2 (Re)ordering categorical variables
Some scoring systems are designed to have a higher score correspond to worse outcome and others are opposite. To specify the order of the categorical levels and allow for correct plotting with the Euler plot (the plots the first level), follow these steps:

While in the same panel (“Prepare” -> “Edit and create data”), click the “Reorder factor levels”, and
order the levels with the first level at the top (drag in the small 3x3 dot grid to the left of the level names), and then
click “Update factor variable”




3.1.5 Now its time for experimentation

Try create categorical variables from the age variable to create a baseline table grouped by age below or above 70.
Create an Euler diagram of age (below/above 70), cohabitation and male sex.
Create and Euler diagram of MFI, MDI (cut-off at 20) and WHO (cut-off at 17). Please note the the WHO should range from 0-100, but the included variable is scaled down by a factor of 4 and ranges 0-25.
…





Damsbo, Andreas Gammelgaard, Kristian Lundsgaard Kraglund, Henriette Nørmølle Buttenschøn, Søren Paaske Johnsen, Grethe Andersen, and Janne Kaergaard Mortensen. 2020. “Predictors for Wellbeing and Characteristics of Mental Health After Stroke.” Journal of Affective Disorders 264 (March): 358–64. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jad.2019.12.032.

title: 4  Further learning
text:
4.1 Where to go next
The FreesearchR project is not affiliated with the listed references below unless stated.
Exercism is a great place to start for open languages (R, Python, Julia or something more exotic), where everything can run in the browser and you don’t need to download anything. You can track your progress and get hints.
